review_title: Good for building entry-level Jewish nonprofit experience
pros:
- Supportive community and culture
-Personal relationships with co-workers and teens
-Events are engaging and fun to be at although sometimes stressful on the staff side, you get to see the direct impact
-Networking and building connections within the Jewish community
-Thoughtful opportunities for learning and professional development
-Summer and immersive experiences help you learn, feel more connected to the organization, and build lasting friendships
-They put great effort into maintaining employees throughout the two + years of the pandemic!
-The day to day isn't too stressful
cons:
-Can feel a bit isolating to be on small teams spread-out across the country
-Hours are inconsistent weekly and you work a lot of evenings and weekends
-As a younger professional having to travel for things like summer experiences, IC, staff conference etc. and then working conventions, kickoffs and local programs it was hard to build community outside of work or have free time
-Need to increase what they pay employees across the board, it's clear more funding its directly put into teens and programs than it is staff
-In our region at times it was hard to build positive relationships with advisors, parents and other community organization due to high staff turnover or previous mistakes of past employees
-Little room for growth unless you are willing to relocate
-You sort of are left to figure it out as you go, and know one really knows your role as well as you do

pros: Many teens were great and impacting their lives was meaningful work
cons: As others have stated, it's extremely nepotistic and they blame staff for the mistakes/poor choices of teenagers.  You will not have healthy work boundaries here - they simply do not exist.  There are also seriously unreasonable expectations of staff to travel and become camp counselors over the summer - rather than catch their breath and/or plan strategically for their primary job responsibilities.  Donors also drive the goals of the agency - not the teens.

job_title: Social Media Associate in Washington, DC
pros: Flexible vacation and work from home policies, working directly with passionate teens, and the ability to speak directly and share ideas with high up employees.
cons: Main con was very quiet, awkward work environment. Everyone had their heads down in their work and didn't collaborate. If you are a social, outgoing person, I wouldn't recommend working here. (This is in reference to the DC office, field staff may have a different experience.) Also, it was very cliquey at all staff gatherings. Other cons include certain things being mandatory that probably shouldn't be. For example, everyone is required to attend a week-long convention through President's Day Weekend, work more than 12 hour days, and is thrown into chaperoning teens even if you have no experience working with teens. It's definitely not the right organization for everyone so just be sure it's a good fit beforehand.
